oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of the steeple of a church in Clifton, N.Y., probably built around 1850. It reflects a combination of Colonial and Post-Colonial architectural styles.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Front of the Masonic Temple (originally District School Number Six), 15 Church St., Pittsford, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of the front of the Masonic Temple, Northfield Lodge No. 426, at 15 Church St. in Pittsford, N.Y. The cobblestone structure was originally built in the 1840s as District School Number 6 by stonemason Samuel Crump. For a fuller description, see Schmidt’s book Cobblestone Masonry (1966). For a description and photograph of the building, plus a detailed example of the masonry, see The Early Architecture of the Genesee Valley (1975).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Entrance door, Gray-Sills House, Kent Road., Orleans County, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of the entrance door to the Gray-Sills House on Kent Road in Orleans County, N.Y. The cobblestone house was built by Mr. Gray in 1836 and later owned by Miss Ethel Sills. The cobblestones are roughly rounded fieldstones laid in the hexagonal recessed panels, so prevalent in the Childs area. The six-panel entrance door is deeply recessed in the cobblestone wall. The half-circle area formed by the stone arch above the transom bar is filled with a solid wood panel. For a fuller description and masonry details see Schmidt's book More Cobblestone House Entrances, Part VII (1963) and The Early Architecture of the Genesee Valley (1975).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Entrance door to the Lockwood House, 1090 Culver Rd., Rochester, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of the main entrance door to the Lockwood House (also known as the Lockwood-Alhart House) at 1090 Culver Rd. in Rochester, N.Y. The cobblestone masonry of the house was done by Alonzo Bradley and features quoins, lintels and window sills of gray limestone. The house was built around 1835 by Roswell Lockwood and acquired by the Alhart Electric Co. in 1949. For a fuller description and measured drawings of various features (including the entranceway) of this house, see Schmidt’s book Cobblestone Masonry (1966).

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of the entrance door to the Solomon Upson House on Ridge Road in Alton, N.Y. This cobblestone house was built in 1847. The cobblestones on the front elevation are small lake-washed stones which are laid in alternating bands of two courses of white stone and two courses of red sandstones. For a fuller description, see The Early Architecture of the Genesee Valley (1975).

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of a front view of the Isaac Chase House (also known as the Chase-Flack House) at 1191 Manitou Rd. in Parma, N.Y. Erected around 1850, the cobblestone house is built of water-washed stones and field stones of various shapes and colors. For a fuller description of the house, as well as measured drawings of the cobblestone masonry and entrance, see Schmidt’s book Cobblestone Masonry (1966).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Entrance porch and door to the Perkins House, 421 East Ave., Rochester, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of the entrance porch and door to the Perkins House (also known as the Erickson-Perkins House, later the Genesee Valley Club ) at 421 East Ave. in Rochester, N.Y. The porch features paired Doric columns set on wide stone piers on each side of the partially recessed steps. The channelled columns and capitals, as well as the entablature, are made of wood. For a fuller description of the house, see The Early Architecture of the Genesee Valley (1975) and Schmidt’s book Greek Revival Architecture in the Rochester Area (1946). Measured drawings of the entrance and other aspects of the house are included in Carl Schmidt's books Fences, Gates and Garden Houses (1963), Greek Revival Architecture in the Rochester Area (1946), and Architectural Mouldings (1967). For a pencil drawing of a different view of this entrance, see Drawings 17 and 92.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Entrance porch, McVean-Minster House, Scottsville-Mumford Road, Town of Wheatland, Monroe County, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of the entrance porch to the McVean-Minster House on Scottsville-Mumford Road in the Town of Wheatland, Monroe County, N.Y. This house is two stories high with the entrance in the center of the front elevation and a single window on each side of the entrance. The entrance consists of a projecting porch with two free-standing square posts, and pilasters against the house, which support the entablature. For a fuller description of the porch see The Early Architecture of the Genesee Valley (1975). Measured drawing of the porch is included in Schmidt's book Greek Revival Details (1968).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Detail of the entablature on the entrance porch of the Perkins House, 421 East Ave., Rochester, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of a detail of the entablature on the entrance porch of the Perkins House (also known as the Erickson-Perkins House, later the Genesee Valley Club ) at 421 East Ave. in Rochester, N.Y. The simple three-member entablature extends around the two-story brick building. The line or break between the frieze and architrave, which are made of plain boards, is the result of beveling the face of the architrave. For a fuller description of the house, see The Early Architecture of the Genesee Valley (1975) and Schmidt’s book Greek Revival Architecture in the Rochester Area (1946). Measured drawings of the entrance and other aspects of the house are included in Carl Schmidt's books Fences, Gates and Garden Houses (1963), Greek Revival Architecture in the Rochester Area (1946), and Architectural Mouldings (1967). For a pencil drawing of a different view of this entrance, see Drawings 17 and 91.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of a cornice on the Kronsbein House (also known as the Langworthy House) on St. Paul Blvd. in Irondequoit, N.Y. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Entrance door to a schoolhouse in Mendon, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of the entrance door to a schoolhouse in Mendon, N.Y. Built around 1836 as the Mendon Academy, it was acquired by Mendon School District No. 2 in 1839 and functioned as a public school until 1950. The cobblestones in the old section of the building were gathered from nearby farms and are of various shapes, colors and sizes, laid four courses per twelve-inch quoin. For a fuller description and detailed drawing of the cobblestone masonry, see Schmidt’s book Cobblestone Masonry (1966). For a photograph and brief description of the building, see The Early Architecture of the Genesee Valley (1975).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Entrance door to the Philip Garbutt House, Garbutt, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of the entrance door to the Philip Garbutt House in Garbutt, N.Y. The two-story ledge-stone house, built around 1825, has the typical Post-Colonial central hall-type plan, with the main entrance facing east toward Union St. The exterior stone walls were covered with a smooth stucco and marked with tool lines to imitate stone joints. It was at one time painted in various bright colors, including yellow on the walls and red on the window sills and lintels. Moses Wells was the carpenter, but the mason is not known. For a fuller description, see The Early Architecture of the Genesee Valley (1975). For measured drawings of certain parlor features, including what Schmidt deemed "one of the most beautiful mantel pieces in the entire Genesee Valley," see Schmidt’s book Colonial and Post-Colonial Details (1969).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rear entrance door to the Culver-Smith-Holahan House at 70 East Blvd., Rochester, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of the rear entrance door to the Culver-Smith-Holander House at 70 East Blvd., Rochester, N.Y. Built between 1816-1818 by Oliver Culver, the house originally stood at the southwest corner of East Avenue and Culver Road and was moved to its present location in 1906. It was once used as a tavern. Caption on drawing: "Side door to the Culver House." For measured drawings of the house, see Schmidt's books Architectural Mouldings (1967) and Colonial and Post-Colonial Details (1969).
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Schmidt, Carl Frederick, 1894-1988
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Doors & doorways; Houses; Architectural elements

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Front of the Abraham Hanford House, 28 Main St., Scottsville, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of the front of the Abraham Hanford House at 28 Main St. in Scottsville, N.Y. Built in the mid-1820's, sections of the house later became part of Slocum's Hardware Store. It was razed in the 1890s and replaced with Windom Hall, now Scottsville Free Library. Caption on drawing: "Restored drawing of the Abraham Hanford House, Scottsville, N.Y." For measured drawings of parts of the house, see Schmidt’s book Colonial and Post-Colonial Details (1969).
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Schmidt, Carl Frederick, 1894-1988
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Historic buildings; Houses; Architectural elements

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Entrance door to the Nathaniel T. Rochester House, S. Washington St., Rochester, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of the entrance door to the Nathaniel T. Rochester House on South Washington St. in Rochester, N.Y. The house, now demolished, was designed by Isaac Loomis and built in 1838 (see front view, Drawing 25 in this collection). The entrance consisted of a door with two vertical panels, flanked by wide mullions and narrow sidelights, with half mullions at the ends. The mullions and half mullions were faced with paneled pilasters with simple moulded caps and bases which supported a wide moulded transom bar and narrow transom sash. The whole was set in a masonry recess with cut stone lintel and sill without any enframement. For a fuller description of the house and doorway, and a measured drawing of the latter, see The Early Architecture of the Genesee Valley (1975).
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Schmidt, Carl Frederick, 1894-1988
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Doors & doorways; Houses; Architectural elements

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Front of the Pardee-Dailey House, 180 Pardee Rd., Irondequoit, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of the Pardee-Dailey House at 180 Pardee Rd. in Irondequoit, N.Y. Built in 1847 by Hiram Pardee. The mason was Henry Clark of Webster, N.Y., and the carpenter was Alexander Wilson. The front is red sandstone cobblestones. See Drawing 8 and Drawing 57, this Collection, for more descriptive information and detailed views of entrance. For a fuller description, see The Early Architecture of the Genesee Valley (1975); for measured drawings of the entrance door, windows, interior details, and cobblestone masonry, as well as more descriptive information, see Schmidt’s book Cobblestone Masonry (1966).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: View of an exterior wall, San Gabriel Mission, San Gabriel, CA
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of an exterior wall of the San Gabriel Mission (Mission San Gabriel Arcangel) at Junipero St. and West Mission Dr. in San Gabriel, CA. Built in the late 18th century of brick, stone, and mortar, it sustained earthquakes in 1804 and 1812 which required replacing arches, the roof, and bell tower.
